Introduction

Immunosuppressants are medications used to dampen pathologic immune responses that are responsible for tissue injury.  They are used to treat autoimmunity (attack against self-antigens, as in rheumatoid arthritis) or alloimmunity (attack against foreign antigens, as in transplant rejection).  Immunosuppressants can be broadly categorized as:



  • Conventional immunosuppressants (older, nonspecific drugs).
  • Biologics (newer, targeted drugs).


This article discusses biologics; a sister article discusses conventional immunosuppressants.

General principles

Conventional immunosuppressants



Conventional immunosuppressants are older drugs that broadly disrupt fundamental processes such as inflammatory gene transcription, DNA synthesis, and cell metabolism (

figure 1
).  They include:



  • Glucocorticoids (eg, prednisone).
  • Calcineurin inhibitors (eg, tacrolimus).
  • Antimetabolites (eg, mycophenolate [MMF], azathioprine [AZP], methotrexate [MTX]).
  • Mammalian (mechanistic) target of rapamycin (mTOR) inhibitors (eg, sirolimus).
  • Cyclophosphamide.


These broad-acting agents suppress multiple innate and adaptive immune cell types simultaneously and tend to have significant systemic toxicity on nonimmune cells.  Depending on the agent and dose, effects may be cytotoxic (triggering apoptosis, used for induction) or cytostatic (arresting proliferation, used for maintenance).  The concepts of induction and maintenance are discussed below.



These agents are small molecules that are orally available, although all of them also have parenteral options.

Biologics or targeted immunosuppressants



Biologics are newer immunosuppressive agents that, unlike conventional drugs, target specific components of the immune system such as individual cytokines or cell surface receptors.  These agents may be monoclonal antibodies ("-mab") or fusion proteins ("-cept").  They include:



  • Anticytokine therapy (eg, infliximab, a tumor necrosis factor alpha [TNF-α] inhibitor).
  • Anti–T-cell therapy (eg, abatacept, a CD80/86 costimulation inhibitor).
  • Anti–B-cell therapy (eg, rituximab, a CD20 monoclonal antibody).
  • Anti-integrin therapy (eg, vedolizumab, a selective leukocyte adhesion inhibitor).
  • Anticomplement therapy (eg, eculizumab, a C5 inhibitor).


Because of their targeted mechanisms, biologics generally cause less systemic toxicity than conventional immunosuppressants.  Most exert cytostatic effects and are used for maintenance therapy, except for rituximab, which can be used for induction.  Because they are large proteins, biologics must be administered parenterally (eg, intravenously, subcutaneously).



Small molecule immunomodulators, although orally available, are often grouped with biologics because they are relatively novel drugs that also have relatively targeted effects.  They include Janus kinase (JAK) inhibitors (eg, baricitinib) and sphingosine-1-phosphate (S1P) modulators (eg, fingolimod), which block cytokine signaling and lymphocyte trafficking, respectively.

Induction and maintenance



Immunosuppressive therapy is typically structured around 2 phases:



  • Induction therapy:  Aims to achieve rapid disease control (ie, remission) in severe or organ-threatening conditions such as acute transplant rejection, certain vasculitides (eg, with rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis), or inflammatory bowel disease (eg, with fistulas or toxic megacolon).  Induction therapy involves high-potency agents with cytotoxic or lymphocyte-depleting effects, including high-dose glucocorticoids (eg, >500 mg/day of intravenous methylprednisolone), cyclophosphamide, rituximab, or antithymocyte globulin.
  • Maintenance therapy:  Aims to keep disease controlled after initial remission has been achieved.  This phase generally favors multiple agents at lower doses, typically in the form of 3-drug regimens used for transplant maintenance immunosuppression (
    figure 2
    ).  These regimens consist of a glucocorticoid (eg, prednisone), a calcineurin inhibitor (eg, tacrolimus), and an antimetabolite (eg, MMF).  Notably, the use of a single biologic agent (eg, infliximab for rheumatoid arthritis) has gained popularity given the simplified dosing and favorable safety profile compared to multidrug regimens.

Corticosteroid-sparing regimens



Glucocorticoids are among the most effective and reliable immunosuppressants and are widely used as a cornerstone of initial therapy.  However, prolonged use is limited by significant toxicity with an increased risk of osteoporosis, metabolic syndrome, adrenal suppression, and steroid-induced myopathy.



Immunosuppression aspires to a corticosteroid-sparing regimen whenever possible, which aims to reduce or eliminate the use of chronic glucocorticoids.  Glucocorticoids are generally tapered off early in the maintenance phase while simultaneously increasing the dose of an alternative conventional immunosuppressant (eg, MTX, AZP) or biologic agent.  Depending on the diagnosis and initial severity, glucocorticoids can be tapered more quickly (eg, over weeks in rheumatoid arthritis with joint involvement only) or more slowly (eg, over a year in giant cell arteritis with optic nerve involvement).

Biologics



Biologics are protein drugs produced using recombinant DNA from living organisms (eg, bacterial, yeast, or mammalian cells).  They include monoclonal antibodies, fusion proteins, and engineered cytokine or receptor mimics.  As large proteins, they must be administered parenterally (eg, intravenously, subcutaneously).  They have the following suffixes:



  • "-mab" (eg, rituximab):  Refers to a monoclonal antibody.
  • "-cept" (eg, etanercept):  Refers to a recombinant fusion protein that tends to mimic a receptor.
  • "-ra" (eg, anakinra):  Refers to a recombinant receptor antagonist.


Biologics are classified according to the part of the immune system they target: cytokines, B cells, T cells, complement, or integrins.

Anticytokine biologics



Anticytokine biologics block proinflammatory cytokines such as TNF-α, IL-1, and IL-6 produced by activated leukocytes.  These cytokines execute end-organ inflammatory responses such as fever, vascular permeability, and tissue destruction (eg, joint cartilage, bowel mucosa).



  • Anti–TNF-α therapy:  Includes monoclonal antibodies to TNF-α (eg, infliximab, adalimumab) or a fusion protein acting as a soluble decoy receptor (eg, etanercept) (
    figure 3
    ).  TNF-α promotes endothelial activation, leukocyte recruitment, and granuloma formation, making it central to diseases that involve both chronic inflammation and organized immune infiltrates.  This explains why anti–TNF-α therapy is used for rheumatoid arthritis (chronic inflammation), inflammatory bowel disease (granulomatous inflammation in Crohn disease), and seronegative spondyloarthropathies such as ankylosing spondylitis and psoriatic arthritis (chronic inflammation).  TNF-α therapy is initiated when disease remains uncontrolled (eg, requiring increasing glucocorticoid requirements) despite the patient already being on first-line therapy with methotrexate.
  • Anti–IL-1 therapy:  Includes monoclonal antibodies against IL-1 (eg, canakinumab), a recombinant receptor IL-1R antagonist (eg, anakinra), or a fusion protein decoy receptor (eg, rilonacept).  IL-1 is produced by inflammasome (eg, cryopyrin, toll-like receptor) activation in innate immune cells such as macrophages and circulating monocytes, with its regulation mostly independent of antigen activation.  Therefore, IL-1 therapy is used for innate autoinflammatory conditions (eg, without autoantibodies or autoreactive T cells) such as Familial Mediterranean Fever, cryopirin-associated periodic syndrome (CAPS), and adult-onset Still disease.
  • Anti–IL-6R monoclonal antibodies (eg, tocilizumab, sarilumab):  Block the IL-6 receptor.  They are primarily indicated for corticosteroid-refractory giant cell (temporal) arteritis, rheumatoid arthritis with an incomplete response to anti–TNF-α therapy, and cytokine release syndrome associated with chimeric antigen receptor (CAR) T-cell therapy.
  • Anti–IL-17 monoclonal antibodies (eg, secukinumab, ixekizumab):  Block the Th17 response, a subset of CD4+ T cells critical for mucoepithelial defense against fungi (eg, Candida spp.).  The Th17 response is hyperactivated in psoriasis and its related spondyloarthropathies (eg, psoriatic arthritis, ankylosing spondylitis).  Anti–IL-17 therapy is used as an alternative (and sometimes preferred) first-line therapy to anti–TNF-α therapy for these conditions.
  • Anti–IL-12/1L-23 monoclonal antibody (eg, ustekinumab):  Blocks the common (p40) subunit of IL-12 and IL-23, which promotes CD4 differentiation into Th1 and Th17 T cells, respectively.  Therefore, its mechanism of action is upstream of the other biologics listed above.  It is used for the treatment of Th1 conditions (eg, inflammatory bowel disease) and Th17 conditions (psoriasis, psoriatic arthritis).


Anticytokine biologics share many adverse effects, including frequent upper respiratory infections (nasopharyngitis), opportunistic infections/reactivation (eg, fungi, tuberculosis, herpes zoster), and possible increased risk of malignancies (eg, lymphomas, nonmelanoma skin cancers).  As parenterally administered proteins, they can cause serum sickness (type III immune complex reaction).  Biologic-specific adverse effects include mucocutaneous candidiasis (anti–IL-17) and demyelination (anti–TNF-α, avoided in multiple sclerosis).

B-cell–targeted biologics



B-cell biologics include monoclonal antibodies against CD20 (rituximab) or B-cell activating factor (belimumab).  These monoclonal antibodies bind to the B-cell surface, targeting them for destruction by NK cells, complement, and macrophages (

figure 4
).  Following administration, effective clinical response is indicated by complete peripheral B-cell depletion.  These biologics are utilized in autoimmune conditions associated with pathogenic autoantibodies.  Such conditions include the following:



  • Granulomatosis with polyangiitis and eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis, associated with antineutrophil cytoplasmic autoantibodies.
  • Pemphigus vulgaris, associated with antidesmosome autoantibodies.
  • Autoimmune hemolytic anemia or idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura, associated with antierythrocyte or antiplatelet autoantibodies.
  • Systemic lupus erythematosus (anti-dsDNA autoantibodies) and rheumatoid arthritis (anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide autoantibodies).


Unique adverse effects include hypogammaglobulinemia, which increases infection risk, particularly in the respiratory tract (eg, bacterial sinusitis, pneumonia).

T-cell–targeted biologics



T-cell biologics include monoclonal antibodies directed against key T-cell surface proteins or cytokine receptors involved in their survival, activation, or proliferation.  Most of these agents are used in the transplant setting to treat or prevent acute cellular rejection:



  • Antithymocyte globulin (ATG):  Polyclonal mixture derived from rabbits or horses immunized with human thymocytes.  It contains immunoglobulins against many T-cell antigens (eg, CD2, CD3, CD4, CD8).  ATG causes widespread and rapid T-cell destruction via antibody- and complement-mediated killing.  It is mainly used to treat severe (corticosteroid-refractory) acute cellular rejection.
  • Anti-CD3 (muromonab):  Monoclonal antibody against CD3.  Like ATG, it also causes rapid T-cell depletion and is used to treat severe acute cellular transplant rejection.
  • Anti–IL-2R (CD25) (basiliximab):  Monoclonal antibody against the IL-2 receptor.  As such, it potently suppresses T-cell proliferation and activation.  It is used mainly for immune preinduction (ie, creating a tolerant environment) immediately prior to organ transplantation, with the goal of preventing acute cellular rejection.
  • Anti-CD80/86 (abatacept):  Fusion protein that binds to CD80/CD86 on antigen-presenting cells (APCs), which is required for costimulation (signal 2) of T cells (
    figure 5
    ).  Without signal 2, T cells become anergic.  Abatacept is used mainly as an alternative to anti–TNF-α therapy for rheumatoid arthritis, psoriatic arthritis, and juvenile idiopathic arthritis.


Adverse effects of T-cell biologics include opportunistic infections and reactivation of latent pathogens (eg, tuberculosis, cytomegalovirus) due to suppressed cellular immunity.  In addition, anti-CD3 and ATG can cause cytokine release syndrome from rapid T-cell lysis, presenting as a flu-like illness that may progress to hypotension or shock.

Complement biologics



Complement biologics (eg, eculizumab, ravulizumab) include monoclonal antibodies that inhibit C5, a protein involved in a terminal step of the complement cascade (

figure 6
).  When C5 is inactivated, the membrane attack complex (C5-C9) cannot form.  Complement inhibitors are used for:



  • Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria:  Involves complement attack against red blood cell membrane proteins, leading to intravascular hemolysis (eg, myoglobinuria).
  • Atypical hemolytic uremic syndrome:  Involves the loss of inhibitory factors, leading to uncontrolled complement activation.  This causes diffuse endothelial injury (especially in glomeruli), leading to acute kidney injury and microangiopathic hemolytic anemia (eg, schistocytes, thrombocytopenia).
  • Refractory cases of myasthenia gravis:  Involve complement activation against nicotinic acetylcholine (nAChR) receptors at the neuromuscular junction.


The main adverse effect associated with complement biologics is an increased risk of infections with encapsulated bacteria, particularly Neisseria meningitidis, which mimics the phenotype of terminal complement deficiency.  Therefore, meningococcal vaccination is required prior to treatment.

Integrin biologics



Integrins are transmembrane adhesion molecules that mediate interactions between cells and the extracellular matrix.  Integrins are needed for leukocytes to adhere to endothelium and migrate into inflamed tissues.  Integrin biologics (eg, vedolizumab, natalizumab) block these interactions, reducing tissue infiltration by immune cells:



  • Vedolizumab (gut selective):  Targets α4β7 integrin, which is specifically expressed on Peyer patches and gut-associated mucosal lymphoid tissue (GALT) T-cells.  It prevents T-cells from trafficking into the bowel wall and is therefore used for inflammatory bowel disease (ulcerative colitis, Crohn disease).
  • Natalizumab:  Targets α4β7 (gut) and α4β1 (blood-brain barrier) integrins and is used for the treatment of ulcerative colitis and some forms of multiple sclerosis.


Thanks to their high selectivity for single integrins, these inhibitors are associated with fewer adverse effects compared to other biologics.

Small molecule immunomodulators



Unlike biologics (which are large proteins, such as monoclonal antibodies), small molecule immunomodulators are orally available drugs that can penetrate cells and dampen intracellular signaling pathways.  They have the following suffixes:



  • "-ib" (eg, baricitinib):  Refers to a JAK inhibitor ("-tinib" refers to tyrosine kinase inhibitors generally).
  • "-mod" (eg, fingolimod):  Refers to an S1P modulator.

JAK inhibitors



JAK inhibitors (eg, baricitinib, tofacitinib, ruxolitinib) are small molecules that block the JAK- STAT (signal transducer and activator of transcription) pathway, which activates the transcription of multiple inflammatory genes including interferon gamma, interleukins, and TNF-α (and is also activated by growth hormone (

figure 7
)).  JAK inhibitors are used as a second- or third-line agent for a variety of conditions including rheumatoid arthritis, inflammatory bowel disease, alopecia areata, and corticosteroid-refractory graft-versus-host disease.  Baracitinib is also used for patients with systemic inflammation from severe COVID-19 infection.

S1P modulators



S1P receptors enable lymphocyte exit from lymph nodes and entry into peripheral blood.  S1P modulators (eg, fingolimod, ozanimod, siponimod) are small molecules that target these receptors, trapping lymphocytes within the nodes, depleting circulating T and B cells, and decreasing tissue inflammation.  They are used for relapsing multiple sclerosis and ulcerative colitis.

Summary



Biologic and targeted immunosuppression inhibit specific immune system components such as cytokines (eg, TNF-α, IL-6), lymphocyte surface antigens (eg, CD3 [T cells], CD20 [B cells]), integrins, and complement proteins.  In contrast to conventional immunosuppressants (glucocorticoids, calcineurin inhibitors, antimetabolites), which nonspecifically interfere with gene transcription, DNA synthesis, and cell metabolism, biologics have a more focused mechanism with less systemic toxicity.  Biologics are large protein drugs (eg, monoclonal antibodies, fusion proteins) and must be administered parenterally.  Most are used for maintenance therapy, though some (eg, rituximab) can also be employed for induction.  Despite their precision, biologics carry risks including opportunistic infections, immunologic hypersensitivity reactions (eg, serum sickness), and increased risk of malignancy.  Oral small molecule immunomodulators (eg, JAK inhibitors, S1P modulators) complement this class by targeting intracellular signaling or lymphocyte trafficking.
